pullRequest.body:
This PR combines several results involving topological sums over `ℤ`. These results are used in #10011 (Hurwitz zeta functions) where sums over `ℤ` feature heavily. 

* Fill in `tsum` and `Summable` variants for lemmas proved for `HasSum`

* Rename some lemmas (with deprecated aliases) to impose a consistent naming scheme

* Generalise several lemmas to allow the target space to be a topological monoid rather than a group.

* Speed up some slow proofs (the old `summable_int_of_summable_nat` took about 10s to compile on my machine, its replacement `Summable.of_nat_of_neg` is 1000 times faster)



---

LGTM, but I think some topology people should also look at this.
LGTM, but I think some topology people should also look at this.
Why not change this to `refine` and at the end `fun n ↦ ?_` while you are at it?

I thought that the proof of this should be much easier, but then I realized that the results I wanted to use have stronger assumptions (`AddCommGroup` instead of `AddCommMonoid`, `T2Space`, ...).
Maybe it's worth adding a comment (or docstring) mentioning that this uses only fairly week assumptions on `α`?

Funnily enough, I originally introduced this lemma myself in a mathlib3 PR over a year ago, and what I wrote was a lemma about topological groups with a proof about 5 lines long. The reviewer (Sebastian Gouëzel) generalized my simple little lemma into the behemoth you see here. (The only change to this lemma in the present PR is renaming it & moving it around slightly.)

I would perhaps argue in favor of calling groups `G` (or maybe `A` when they are additive) consistently, rather than using the pretty generic `α`. But doing this everywhere would be a lot of work... (and my feelings are not particularly strong).
It feels weird to me to prove a general statement for a general function `g`, but to apply it just to the specific function `f`. Why not just write it as: `HasSum f (m + f 0)`?

I'm not sure whether `Int.negSucc n` is really the normal form we want to use -- it feels more like an implementation detail of the integers in Lean. What about using `- (n+1)` instead (which is defeq)? Note I'm not sure of myself here, as I don't think there is a simp lemma converting the former to the latter, so it might be worth asking on Zulip what people think.

I actually had the same feeling, but didn’t want to unilaterally change the existing formulations. Since you don’t like the negSucc formulations either, I have pushed a change.

> I'm not sure whether `Int.negSucc n` is really the normal form we want to use -- it feels more like an implementation detail of the integers in Lean. What about using `- (n+1)` instead (which is defeq)? Note I'm not sure of myself here, as I don't think there is a simp lemma converting the former to the latter, so it might be worth asking on Zulip what people think.
